name: Telegram Bot
title: Telegram Bot

children.text: Telegram is a cloud-based instant messaging service that offers secure, encrypted communication, media sharing, and group chat capabilities.
With the Telegram Bot modules in
, you can manage messages, share various media types, and send media by URL or ID,  edit media messages and message captions, download files, and perform other actions.
Telegram account on a desktop app
In order to use the Telegram app, you have to provide your mobile phone number.

children.text: Enter the product name for which you want to send invoice.
A Bot-defined invoice payload, 1-128 bytes. This will not be displayed to the user, use for your internal processes.
Three-letter ISO 4217 currency code, see more on
Add the product label and price details.
The maximum accepted amount for tips in the smallest units of the currency (integer, not float/double). For example, for a maximum tip of
, it shows the number of digits past the decimal point for each currency (2 for the majority of currencies). Defaults to 0
Add the tip amounts suggested for this invoice.
Enter the unique identifier for the target message thread (topic) of the forum (for forum supergroups only).

Unique deep-linking parameter. If left empty, forwarded copies of the sent message will have a Pay button, allowing multiple users to pay directly from the forwarded message, using the same invoice. If non-empty, forwarded copies of the sent message will have a URL button with a deep link to the bot (instead of a Pay button), with the value used as the start parameter
A detailed description of required fields should be provided by the payment provider.
Enter URL address of the product photo for the invoice. Can be a photo of the goods or a marketing image for a service.
Select whether if you require the user's full name to complete the order
Select whether if you require the user's phone number to complete the order.
Select whether if you require the user's email address to complete the order.
Select whether if you require the user's shipping address to complete the order.
Select whehter if the user's phone number should be sent to the provider.
Select whether if the user's email address should be sent to the provider.
Select whether Pass true if the final price depends on the shipping method.
Select whether you disable notifications. IF so, sends the message silently. iOS users will not receive a notification; Android users will receive a notification with no sound.

Enter the ID of the file already uploaded to the Telegram server.
Creates an additional invite link for a chat.
Edits a non-primary invite link created by the bot.

Retrieves a list of updates from the Telegram server. By default, updates starting with the earliest unconfirmed update are returned. If you want to list more, you need to set the offset. This module cannot be used with webhooks. To use this module, you must switch off and remove all your Telegram webhooks.

List available Telegram chats. By default, chats starting with the earlier unconfirmed update are returned. If you want to list more, you need to set the offset. This module cannot be used with webhooks. To use this module, you must switch off and remove all your Telegram webhooks.
Revokes an invite link created by the bot.
Triggers when there is a new update from your Telegram Desktop Application.
The Watch updates trigger cannot be combined with the Get Updates or Get Chats modules.
Retrieves a list of administrators from a selected chat.
Get the Number of Members in a Chat
Use this module to get the number of members in a chat.
Use this method to kick a user from a group, a supergroup, or a channel. The bot must be an administrator in the chat for this to work and must have the appropriate admin rights.
Promotes or demotes a user in a supergroup or a channel. The bot must be an administrator in the chat for this to work and must have the appropriate admin rights.
Restricts a user in a supergroup.
Performs an arbitrary authorized API call.
Sends an answer to an inline query.
You can look for Telegram Bot templates in
, where you'll find thousands of pre-created
Check the following procedures if you are facing difficulties when using the Telegram bot app.
How to find out the ID of a private channel/group
One possible way to determine the ID of a private channel/group is as follows:
Place Telegram Bot >; Watch updates module in the Make.
Configure the module by creating a webhook.
Send a message to the private channel/group.
Verify the output of the module by clicking the bubble above the module.
Find the ID in the output bundle:
How to find out the user ID
To find out the ID of a Telegram user, forward their message to the
. Check out the following procedure for steps on how to do that:
to your Telegram app. You can do that by entering
in the search bar and selecting the
Go to the chat with the user you want to retrieve the ID from.
Copy the User ID and paste it to the Make module.
Adding Your Bot To the Channel
Click the right mouse button on the channel name and select the
icon next to the member number.
Start typing the name of your bot in the search field.
Click on the bot name to select the bot you want to add to the channel.
Make the bot admin by clicking the respective button.
Assign the permissions to your bot and click the
The bot has been added to the channel.
To test the public channel you need to obtain the
is part of the channel link.
If the public channel link is, for example,
Now, you can send a message to the public channel using the
Send a Text Message or a Reply
You need to obtain the Chat ID to test the private channel. There are three options to retrieve the ID:

data.label: Telegram Bot
data.overridedLabel: Retrieve the ID from the web version of Telegram

children.text: Retrieve the ID from the web version of Telegram
Switch the private channel to the public channel, then retrieve the ID (by sending or receiving the message in Make) and switch back the channel type to
to your private channel and using the
Retrieving the ID From the Web Version of Telegram
Log in to your Telegram account via
Click on the private channel you want to retrieve the chat ID for.
Copy the number between the c letter and the underscore from the URL. If the URL is
Paste the number to the desired field and
The Chat ID of the private channel is then
You can now use the ID in the desired Telegram Bot module in Make.
It is not required. You can sign in on the site,
where you can change your public settings. You will receive a key in your desktop application to submit your login.
My bot is hitting limits, how do I avoid this?
When sending messages inside a particular chat, avoid sending more than one message per second. We may allow short bursts that go over this limit, but eventually you'll begin receiving 429 errors.

If you're sending bulk notifications to multiple users, the API will not allow more than 30 messages per second or so. Consider spreading out notifications over large intervals of 8—12 hours for best results.
Also note that your bot will not be able to send more than 20 messages per minute to the same group.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
